title: Fake puffins used to encourage endangered birds back to island abandoned after 'killer rat invasion'
text:
The cliffs of the Calf of Man appear abundant with puffins, a species threatened with global extinction, but upon closer inspection the seabirds are not all that they seem.

Over 100 decoy puffin statues, purchased from a garden centre, have been placed on the 600 acre island off the southern tip of the Isle of Man in an attempt to draw the real thing back to the island.

Now experts say the plan could be working, after puffins were spotted landing on the island for the first time in decades.

Around 800 individual birds would rest around the Calf's coastal waters in 1996, but experts believe the last year puffins bred on the Calf of Man was 1985.

The island, described as an ideal habitat, was abandoned by the puffins after a killer rat invasion, which would eat the birds eggs and chicks.

The invasive brown rat are thought to have first made it to the island over 200 years ago, but the population exploded and the numbers of puffins and other native seabirds, such as the Manx Shearwater, drastically dropped.
description: The cliffs of the Calf of Man appear abundant with puffins, a species threatened with global extinction, but upon closer inspection the seabirds are not all that they seem.
